Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC - GOALI Fundamental Research: Gallium Nitride Optical Isolation for Wide Bandgap Power Electronic Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks funding for the Center for Grid Connected Advanced Power Electronics Systems (GRAPES) studies conducted by the University of Arkansas site (lead) and the University of South Carolina site. Funding Requests for Fundamental Research are authorized by an NSF approved solicitation, NSF 10-507. The solicitation invites I/UCRCs to submit proposals for support of industry-defined fundamental research.

The technical merit of this project is in advancing the state of the art in fully-integrated, fullywide-bandgap, fully-isolated power electronic converters based on GaN. This will produce new state-of-the-art boundaries in switching speeds, volumetric reduction, power density, temperature of operation, efficiency, and immunity to interference. Eventually, these technologies will be applied to grid-connected systems. The outcome from this fundamental effort has the potential for transforming how power electronic systems are designed for numerous smart-grid and power converter applications. The team of participating university faculty is very well qualified to conduct the project and they are supported by capable and knowledgeable professionals from their industry members. It is a creative proposal that is well conceived in that it takes a practical, proof-of-concept approach to the problem. Both universities are well equipped with excellent facilities to perform their respective research tasks.

The proposed project has the potential to make a huge societal impact if their approach is proven successful for the development of more integrated, less expensive and more efficient power electronics for converter and power grid applications. The research plan engages graduate students in the research effort and will have an influence on undergraduate students as well. Many of the participating students are expected to come from underrepresented minority groups. The research results will be distributed broadly and communicated directly to key industry representatives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This fundamental research project was a cooperative effort between the University of Arkansas and the University of South Carolina. The research goal was to develop high-performance optical control for silicon carbide (SiC) and gallium nitride (devices). In recent years there has been a dramatic increase in the penetration of switching power converters in virtually all areas of technology. These switching power converters can be found at an extremely wide range of voltage and power levels: from less than one volt in microprocessors up to hundreds of kilovolts in electric power transmission. In particular the interest in integrating renewable energy into the electric power grid, which will require much more flexible and adaptable controls, has sparked a real need for power converters that can function at higher voltages, temperatures, and switching frequencies. Wide bandgap materials such as SiC and GaN have superior material characteristics that would address these needs. GRAPES researchers collaborated to investigate these materials, primarily focusing on GaN, to understand and develop optical isolation methods that can operate at high temperatures, high speeds, and in conjunction with gate drivers that can be used in these converters.

Unfortunately, after extensive work, it was discovered that GaN optical isolators were not ready to achieve the specifications of the power devices under study. Specifically, it was discovered that optical switches using GaN are too slow to be of use in high-speed switching converters. Additional research is required before a high temperature solution is available that would be attractive in driving SiC and GaN power switches. So, while the ultimate goal of the research could not be achieved, researchers did identify a number of needed research tasks that have continued to drive research proposals both for GRAPES and our broader research focus.

At the University of Arkansas, the research was led by Dr. Alan Mantooth. At the University of South Carolina, the work was led by Dr. Enrico Santi. The majority of the student research activities at the UA were performed by Jake Williams. Mr. Williams graduated with his M.S.E.E.  in 2012 and went to work for Freescale Semiconductor. In addition, six REU students were funded and accomplished tasks that contributed to this work. Whenever possible, these students were invited to attend our November GRAPES Meeting to present their work to the GRAPES IAB, providing them with valuable face-to-face time with IAB members. Two of these students subsequently interned with IAB members, providing a benefit to both the students and the members.
